value: Sketches of Riverboats, Tracery, Numbers, and Chain Link

label: Description
value: Six sketches arranged on a vertical sheet. At top left a wood-hulled riverboat is viewed from the side, and also from the bow and stern.  Below this is a sketch of the date 1600, the numerals formed by  pieces of ironwork with prominent joints.  To the right, a late Gothic style tracery window which the artist notes was created with brick and not stone.  Above at right are two sketches of a chain with ring- and diamond-shaped links.  The diamond-shaped links have spiked projections on either flat side of the link, making it, as the artist notes, difficult upon which to sit.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Dutch Farm House / Walk from Enkhuigen [sic] to Hoorn

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet torn with bottom half missing, leaving a rough bottom edge.  Depicted in center of sheet is a large timber-frame house with a chimney.  The house consists of three stories at one corner - the elevation is articulated by projecting stringcourses and terminates in a 'trapgevel' façade.  Adjacent at the ground level are two windows, one with a shutter hanging askew from its hinge.  At this corner of the house, one section up to the second story has been removed to create a round-arched entrance.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet consisting of six sketches.  Beginning at top right are two small sketches of dormers.  The upper example is seen from below and covers a shuttered window.  The dormer element ends in a three-sided projection with decorative metalwork cresting at the joints topped with a tall finial above.  The lower example is viewed from teh front and it has a projecting pyramidal overhang, topped by a spike finial, similar to a lightening rod.  Below this is a sketch of the arms of the town of Hoorn: a unicorn with its head turned to its left, rearing up on the legs of a gargoyle clutching in its hooves a shield with curled sides.  At bottom right is a sketch of a double gable masonry house, its 'trapgevel' façade punctuated by iron rod ends to support the stones.   At left is a small lookout tower seen from below.  The side of this structure has three windows, ending in a drop finial.  Above left  is the Hospital of Hoorn, a tall masonry building with its façade articulated by five levels with stepped ends and scrolling ornament.  The window and entrance openings at the ground level are defined by quoins.  There is a Palladian window at the center above the entrance flanked by single round-arched windows on either side.  There are four smaller quare shuttered openings; the one at the building's far left has a small lantern projecting from a bracket.  The window scheme of the upper stories is similar but a triangular pediment is substituted over the windows.  The building bears a date plaque of 1563.  To the building's far right is a smaller, simpler three-story building bearing a date plaque of 1723.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a large, eclectically adorned masonry Romanesque structure with later additions.  The building's main elevation terminates in a corner, while the rest of the building is rounded toward the rear.  Very small timber-frame structures are seen in the foreground.  The building's character is in keeping with the Northern Renaissance style: it has a steeply pitched roof culminating in a large, four-sided clocktower with a galleried, octagonal double cupola and tall ornamental finial.  The façade's lower elevation consists of a row of blind trefoils, a row of small windows above, and another small blind arcade before the attic story.  There are turrets at the façade corners, and another in the center of the façade upon which sits a unicorn bearing the arms of the town of Hoorn.  A date plaque above reads 1532-1651 in a banner.  Visible at the rear of the building is a rounded façade with blind arcade.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
A Few of the Mills at Zaandam

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet bound vertically in album.  Study of many windmills in an open, marshy landscape.  In the foreground are short grasses.  At a further distance in the midground is a large windmill at center right, seen from the side.  The mill consists of an octagonal central tower that graduates in diameter until  it is capped by a rounded roof from which large blades spin.  Two large supports buttress the roof and are anchored into the short story beneath the tower.  This tower and another to its right bear a striped flag with three bands of color - the center band is lighter than the upper and lower bands.  Similar mills are seen along the horizon.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Staircase 2nd Half XVII century from Cologne / Museum at Amsterdam

label: Description
value:
Vertical sheet depicting on recto a wooden balcony or gallery and circular staircase with balustrade sketched quickly, containing many inscriptions by the artist defining the details which are not fully worked.  The horizontal balcony element is supported by a heavy beam, the end post terminating at top and bottom with "cupid faces" as defined by the artist.  Below the beam at right is a figural wood corbel that the artist describes as "wooden... / support bar".  The newel post at the top of the staircase has "a lion with shield and arms (not so high)"; underneath the newel post opposite to this, presumably hanging from the beam obscured by the staircase, is what the artist describes as "a pendant under this post" in the shape of "a monkey".  The staircase is carved along the top edge and has what the artist defines as a "scroll, small french curve" below.  The rail is connected to the baseboard by balusters, and consists of three registers: a "leaf" at top, a "scroll" in the middle, and "leaf egg" with a "bead" below.  The treads at the bottom of the staircase fan out into a curved bottom stop wider than the rest of the staircase.  The artist notes to the right of the bottom newel post "columns .... around it".  

Depicted on verso is a small band of scrolls contained in a rectangle; another small sketch of wavy lines framed by beading at top and bottom.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting two sketches drawn at Haarlem.  At left is a tall, narrow steeple on top of a square tower.  The tower is masonry in an earlier Romanesque or Gothic style, with two louvered lancets visible with a blind arcade above.  The tower corners are topped with crockets which are connected by slender (possibly iron) supports.  From this base rises an octagonal clock tower in a more fully executed Gothic or late Gothic style. It can be divided into four levels: at the bottom, a flamboyent Gothic tracery opening at each side; above this, another openwork lancet gallery with crockets at the corners; finally, a blind arcade with small cupola surmounted by a crocketed, opework onion dome with spike and ball finial.   The other sketch at right, as noted by the artist, is a "balcony or gallery / on the hotel de ville / Haarlem". The rectangular gallery has a small balustrade which supports five Ionic columns upon which sits a deep and heavy cornice.  The gallery is supported from below by five scrolling modillions.  The artist notes the "modillion" molding "supporting the" cornice's "overhang", and that the columns have "good Ionic proportions".

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Gate of Amsterdam at Haarlem, Inside View

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating a walkway that leads to a large, pointed arch opening in a massive masonry city gate.  Above the entrance is another pointed arch lancet window with four glazed panels. Rusticated quoins define the openings of both arches.  At the same height as this window are two turrets with octagonal domes and ball finials.  A clock is seen at the top of the façade, and behind it, the steeply  pitched roofs of the various towers on the other side of the gate.  The gate seems to straddle a water source, as the road rises in the center from the grass alongside, and a road or pathway is raised up on supports perpendicular to the gate.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Sketch of Cathedral Tower and Doorway

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with two sketches: above, a Romanesque cathedral tower with noticeable additions.  The tower's façade is articulated by three tall lancet window openings with louvers (possibly containing a bell within).  A small arcaded tracery balustrade is below.  Above the lancets is a broken pediment that projects upward, surmounted by ball finials at the three corners of the pediment.  At right is another finial; at left, a short masonry element supporting a flag.   This story has a small gallery that projects forward.  Beneath these projections are tall, slender masonry supports creating an openwork lancet.  The drawing on the lower half of the sheet is a detailed sketch of a Baroque doorway.  The doors are framed by an arch with quoins and doric columns supporting a thick cornice. Above each column is a lion facing the other.  The façade continues behind them: a broken pediment is raised up ending in a semicircular cap.  Large c-scrolls at either side further define the imposing pediment.  Behind this is the continuation of a wall with a gallery at right.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on green paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Sketches of Ironwork, Mills and Riverboats

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet consisting of sketches in three registers.  At top of sheet, four tie rod ends of various configurations are depicted, one from the front and in profile.  As the artist's inscription indicates, these are "Ties" from "Dordricht".  The ties are medieval in style, consisting of a long spike with a square join in the center. The spike splits into a Y, with the ends terminating in small openwork crockets.  In the center register from left is another, longer tie rod end, a well developed sketch of a mill seen in profile from the left, and a small riverboat.  At the bottom half of the sheet are depicted from left another riverboat that is larger and with more rigging visible than that illustrated above, and another mill seen from the rear.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on buff paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped into album vertically.  At left is a brown mill seen from the front, small lighter brown buildings are seen in the foreground.  There is a sketchy indication of trees and perhaps a green, marshy area adjacent to a body of water.  At right is another small mill and the indication of similar buildings at right.  The sky is thick with clouds breaking as though a storm was blowing in or had just ended.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  In the center of the midground, a mill is seen from the front at a distance in a marshy landscape.  The view of the artist is from across a body of water where marsh grasses are indicated, and the water deep enough for two small boats to navigate it.  The mast and sails of two boats are visible at left and right of the mill, further obscured by the grasses in the foreground.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Seen from a distance are a group of brown mills.  In the foreground is a body of water, its shallows punctuated by small groups of grasses, which become more dense in the direction of the mills.  The sky is thick with dark grey clouds at the horizon.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on thick off-white wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with view of buildings on either side of a narrow road with figures.  The road bends to the right, and lining the street at left are multi-story half-timbered structures, their second stories overhanging deeply and supported by larger wooden brackets.  Many have their shutters open, and the upper story windows shielded by a canopy when the shutters are not present.  The roofs are steeply pitched and lined with tiles.  At the bottom of the sheet, the artist has given a guide for colors seen here.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Illustrated is a large, square timbered building with two arcaded stories enclosed by a railing of crossed timbers.  This building is on the bank of a river, its lower story having two windows flanking a door which opens directly onto the water.  Three small wooden piles outside the door allow a boat to be moored next to the structure.  A railing lines the riverbank at right, and the elevations of similar structures are seen in the background.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a multi-story timbered building with very steep tiled roof.  The building is seen from a canted corner, and only its upper levels are illustrated.  The roof has two tiers of dormers, and the roof corners terminate in finials consisting of balls on spikes.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting three sketches of architectural details.  At left, a slender tower with octagonal domed cupola rises from a tiled roof.  Adjacent to the base of the tower is a cross seen in a three-quarter view.  The tower consists of two repeated sections: an arcade topped by an octagonal dome, that is surmounted by a tall finial with a ball and weathervane.  According to the artist's inscription, the cupola is made of "black slate / and wood / painted black."  At upper right is a very low dormer over a window that breaks the tiled roofline of, as the artist notes, a "convent / Baden."  Below right is the detailed sketch of a two-story dormer with glazed window and half-timbering decoration on the facade.  The artist notes that in the "top window there is a swinging oak bracket / for handing things up with."

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on gray paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting an elaborate black ironwork railing, as the artist notes, is from an altar.   At left the railing begins with a thick square post decorated with very small gold quatrefoils (possibly blind?), and terminates in a tall post that emerges from what the artist calls a "sort of serpents head," and is capped by a ball finial.  The decorative frieze of the railing adjacent to the post is in the shape of repeated figure 8, which trails into a single rod of metal that makes large scrolls (according to the artist's notation, this is "12 in".  The scrolls regularly terminate in the head of either a dolphin or a parrot.  The scrollwork meets what is likely the center of the railing where the letters IHS painted golden yellow are inscribed in two confronted scrolls that create the shape of a heart.  Beyond this the scrollwork is only rendered faintly with watercolor to indicate the railing's continuation.  Below this are two sets of ironwork of the same pattern, a heart shape similar to that in the section of railing above, although only scrolling and foliate elements highlighted in gold are contained therein.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value:
Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Ornamental railing with faceted, tapered newel post ending in a ball finial.  The railing consists of two levels of scrolling ornament with joints highlighted in golden yellow.  The scrollwork terminates in small flowers, also in golden yellow.  A small, detailed drawing of one of the flowers is positioned to the upper right of the drawing of the railing and is noted as I, which corresponds to a small flower in the railing that is rendered less clearly. 

Related to railing depicted in 1943-51-119.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value:
Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Ornamental railing with faceted, tapered newel post ending in a ball finial.  The railing consists of two levels of scrolling ornament with joints highlighted in golden yellow.  The scrollwork of the upper section terminates in small flowers, also in golden yellow.  The lower section consists of confronted scrolls joined by a flame-like central element.   In the field above and to the right of the railing are three small flowers or quatrefoils and the flame-like element drawn in greater detail.  Each is numbered I through IV, and correspond to decorative elements in the railing also noted numbers I through IV. 

Related to railing depicted in 1943-51-119, 1943-51-120.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Studies of Buildings and Ornament, Freudenstadt

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet containing three sketches. Above, a detail of a winged, serpent-like creature resting its arms on a slanting support, and its tail curled upward.  According to the artist's inscription, this is an "arm to a church stall".  Below left is a small square building with steeply pitched roof and 'trapgevel' façade nestled in a dense stand of trees.  At lower right, the steeple of a Romanesque masonry tower.  The steeple has two octagonal levels, the uppermost topped by a tall cupola and small square tower with ball finial and weathervane.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding depicting a timbered, covered bridge over a body of water.  At left is a building in the distance, while at right are bushes.  The arch of the bridge frames the view of small buildings alongside the riverbank.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating five sketches of buildings or architectural elements.  Beginning at top left is a simple, timber-frame structure with steeple in the center of the main façade.  The eaves are ornamented with bargeboard decoration underneath.  At top right is a small ogee canopy over an open casement window.  The canopy appears to be tiled.  This small sketch is identified by the artist as "Forsbach / Valley of the Murg / Black Forest".  At center is a half-timbered building with steeply pitched roof, and the artist has noted a small addition to the corner of the building which is prominently supported by large timbers underneath.  At lower right is a small tower with faceted onion dome cupola and four-sided finial or weathervane.  The drawing at lower left is much larger than the others, and illustrates a shingeled, timber-frame structure with two story tower completed by a tiled steeple with ball finial surmounted by a cross.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Heidelberg Castle from the Bridge over the Necker

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.  Depicted is a large castle complex on a hill surrounded by trees.  The central building is multistoried with a steeply pitched roof and turret visible.  Behind this is a lower windowed building that terminates in a larger, octagonal four-story tower.  Lower buildings are joined in front of the central building, with a fortified, semicircular structure overlooking the bluff.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet illustrating two sketches of architectural details.  At left, a section of a masonry building façade that is heavily decorated with scrolling ornament.  There are two windows with triangular pediments, and the top of the façade projects upward to a pedestal upon which stands the sculpture of a figure.  At right is a very simple tower surmounted by an onion dome with a smooth surface only interrupted by a small chimney stack.  Without interruption, the top of the dome becomes an octagonal steeple with tall finial and decorative banner or weathervane at its top.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with frayed bottom and right edge.  Illustrated are sketches of buildings and architectural features.  Beginning from top left are two domed steeples, both with shingled onion-shaped cupolas and tall finials. At right is an elevation of a timbered building with a large, deep gable on both stories which shade open windows with shutters.  In the center is a very small sketch of a dormer within a shingled or tiled roof.  At lower left is likely the same gabled building sketched on the  upper half of the sheet, but now viewed from a corner angle, the gables supported by very large timbers which the artist identifies as being "at least 3 ft."  At lower right is a very quickly sketched tiled or shingled roof with an awkwardly oversize "bell" cupola, as it is named by the artist.  The cupola projects from the roof on a very thin support, and balloons above it.  The cupola is shingled, and terminates in a small ball finial with weathervane.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite, on cream wove paper tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with two sketches of buildings.  At left is a half-timbered building with a shingled or tiled steeply pitched roof that has a very deep overhang.  The building is raised up on tall timber supports that create a framed archway beneath the first story, which has a white façade and two windows with green shutters.  The sketch at right is possibly the same building seen at lower right in 1943-51-127.  It is a long building also with a steeply pitched shingled or tiled roof that is canted at the end.  A clock face is visible in a triangular roof dormer.  Above this is a bell-shaped cupola surmounting a very thin structure.  The cupola has a tall finial with ball and weathervane ornament.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor over graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with small drawing in upper left corner depicting a half-timber structure seen from one side.  The roof is steeply pitched and there are two deep eaves visible.  There is a balcony below a window that is supported from below by large timbers.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Grand Central Terminal, New York, NY: Design for Façade

label: Description
value: South facade of lower and upper story, with stairway leading up to the main entrance at center.  Five bays, alternately of different sizes, are placed between the corner projections. Roof ornamentation suggested at upper center of upper story.

label: Physical description
value: Pen and black ink, graphite on cream tracing paper

label: Provenance
value: Mrs. William Greenough; 1943: acquired by Museum

label: Notes
value: South facade of lower and upper story, with stairway leading up to the main entrance at center. Five bays, alternately of different sizes, are placed between the corner projections. Roof ornamentation suggested at upper center of upper story.

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with sketches of timber structures and architectural details.  At top left is a round-arched leaded glass window composed of round glass lenses and promient metal bars dividing the window vertically and horizontally.  At right is the façade of a timber and plaster building with its upper stories fully rendered.  The building has a tiled roof, deep eaves, and a projecting canopy.  At center left are two sketches: the shuttered window of a water shed, and the detail of cross-beam paneling below.  Below these is another quickly sketched half-timbered building (possibly the same as that shown above right).  At bottom right is a stable seen from the side.  Its has a pair of double doors with an open timbered slats above.  Its right side is timber and plaster with a stone course below.  It has a single door opening with a small square window to its proper right.  Above this is another square window with prominent strap hinges also at proper right.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with six sketches of architectural details.  At the top are two different styles of chimneys with the artist's notes about colors and material.  Below this at left is the detail of the underside of an eave with the artist's notes again about material and and position of the elements, specifically "to let / floor beams protrude / as far as possible / under overhang and / to fill up betweenwith plaster / it gives / softness". To the right of this is a lightly sketched timber structure with a prominent dormer and roof with deep eaves visibly supported by beams from underneath.  Below this drawing is another half-timber and plaster stucture identified as a "farm house".  At bottom right is a large half-timbered building with masonry lower story and a low, swooping wooden eave supported by y-shaped timbers at the front.  A smaller timber structure with steeply pitched roof is attached to the rear.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet containing three sketches of buildings.  At top left is the upper section of a half-timbered structure. At top right is a timber building with a tall tiled roof with a small dormer at the corner.  At center is a half-timber building with smaller shed at the front, and a water source flows from under the building's right corner.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Three Views of Gargoyles, Baden Baden

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting two gargoyles: one is depicted from both the front and side, while the other below is only shown from the side. Each is mounted at a ninety-degree angle to an elaborate scrolling metal bracket.  The bracket and gargoyles have been tinted green, as if to imply a painted or patinated copper surface.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with one sketch of a Romanesque gate.  The masonry gate has a small archway at its base, two stair turrets at either corner with crenellation at their tops, a high peaked roof in the center, and a clock on its façade.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet containing two sketches of belfries.  The belfry at left is a small Gothic tower which projects from a tiled roof.  The tower has a stonework lancet on all sides and small bell visible in the center.  Its roof rises to a very narrow steeple and is adorned on all sides by very finely worked crockets.  The other belfry at right is also Gothic in style but much more simple, rising from a short octagonal tower and encircled by a gallery.  It has a paneled roof that rises to a narrow steeple with small ball finial at top.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with five sketches of architectural details.  Depicted in the upper half of the sheet are two belfries, each with a gilt ball finial, as noted by the artist.  Below this at left is a chimney top with two rows of openings topped by a small pitched, tile roof.  At bottom left is a doorway framed by quoins.  At right is balcony with balustrade viewed from below.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Ironwork, Door to City Hall, Basle (Basel)

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet depicting a doorway with an iron gate framed by ashlar masonry with an open transom above filled with elaborately interlocking and scrolling ironwork.  The ironwork of both the transom and the gate are magnified in detail in two sketches below.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with numerous sketches of architectural elements.  Clockwise from bottom left: a dormer with ogee-shaped roof, gutter, and small gargoyle spout at the corner.  This same spout is drawn to the left.  Above this is a horizontal fountain spout in the shape of a man blowing into a pipe.  In the top half of the sheet are three sketches: below left is a window made of five round-arched lancets that graduate in size. The window is flanked by louvered shutters.  Above is the arched top of a doorway filled with greyish black scrolling ironwork.  At right is a dormer with a tiled roof that cantilevers far over the window opening below it.  The cantilever is supported by ogee brackets on either side of the window.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Railing and Wall Decoration of Hospital, St. Ambrose, Milan

label: Description
value: Vertical sheet with three sketches. At top right is a section of wall decoration from Sant'Ambrogio, Milan.  One quadrant of a sunburst is depicted with green, pink, and yellow wavy rays emanating from the center.  To the left of this is  graphite version of the entire motif, like a pinwheel with alternating shaded arms.  Below this is a railing section with vertical members filled with squares of scrolling ironwork.

label: Physical description
value: Brush and watercolor, graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
Old Castle of the Gonzagas, Mantova

label: Description
value: Horizontal sheet tipped vertically into binding.

label: Physical description
value: Graphite on cream paperboard tipped into binding with fabric
